metadata.title: Some simple rules for estimating reproduction numbers in the presence of reservoir exposure or imported cases

abstract.text: For many diseases, the basic reproduction number (R 0 ) is a threshold parameter for disease extinction or survival in isolated populations. However no human population is fully isolated from other human or animal populations. We use compartmental models to derive simple rules for the basic reproduction number in populations where an endemic disease is sustained by a combination of local transmission within the population and exposure from some other source: either a reservoir exposure or imported cases. We introduce the idea of a reservoir-driven or importation-driven disease: diseases that would become extinct in the population of interest without reservoir exposure or imported cases (since R 0 < 1), but nevertheless may be sufficiently transmissible that many or most infections are acquired from humans in that population. We show that in the simplest case, R 0 < 1 if and only if the proportion of infections acquired from the external source exceeds the disease prevalence and explore how population heterogeneity and the interactions of multiple strains affect this rule. We apply these rules in two case studies of Clostridium difficile infection and colonisation: C. difficile in the hospital setting accounting for imported cases, and C. difficile in the general human population accounting for exposure to animal reservoirs. We demonstrate that even the hospital-adapted, highly-transmissible NAP1/RT027 strain of C. difficile had a reproduction number <1 in a landmark study of hospitalised patients and therefore was sustained by colonised and infected admissions to the study hospital. We argue that C. difficile should be considered reservoir-driven if as little as 13.0% of transmission can be attributed to animal reservoirs.

FIGREF21.text: Case study: Clostridium difficile16    Clostridioides difficile (also known as Clostridium difficile) is a 17 bacterium that colonises the intestines of many mammals includ-18 ing humans and livestock (Hensgens et al., 2012). Most human 19 hosts do not have symptoms despite being colonised. Colonisa-20 tion is typically transient, lasting approximately one month in 21 adults (Johnson et al., 1992), due to competition and interactions 22 with other intestinal flora (Britton and Young, 2012). Disruption 23 of the gut flora, often caused by consumption of antibiotics or 24 proton-pump-inhibitors, allows C. difficile to proliferate in large 25 numbers (Britton and Young, 2012). Toxigenic strains of C. difficile 26 then produce a number of toxins that can cause diarrhoea which 27 is often severe and sometimes life-threatening (Voth and Ballard, 28 2005). A robust immune response to these toxins is able to 29 neutralise their effect (Kelly and Kyne, 2011) and most of the pop-30 ulation have anti-toxin antibodies starting at a young age (Viscidi 31 et al., 1983). Immune responses protect against symptoms but 32 not protect against colonisation (Loo et al., 2011). Asymptomat-33 ically colonised carriers are also infectious (Riggs et al., 2007) 34 while animal models have shown that disruption of gut flora, 35 even in the absence of symptoms, increases spore shedding and 36 infectiousness (Lawley et al., 2009).

Under these assumptions, approximately 32 out 25 of 150 (21%) colonisations or infections with NAP1/RT027 were 26 present at admission. Of the approximately 10% of cases that 27 were colonised or infected for some part of their hospital stay, 28 approximately 3% were with NAP1/RT027 and the remaining 7% 29 were with other types. Though colonisation with non-toxigenic 30 strains appears to be protective against infection with toxigenic 31 strains (Gerding et al., 2015), we do not have good information 32 about the interaction of C. difficile types. Nevertheless, we can use 33 the argument we presented in Section 5 to bound the invasion 34 reproduction number. This becomes as in Box II 35 The basic reproduction number (i.e. in a completely suscepti-36 ble population without competition with other types) is slightly 37 greater (see Box III) 38 This suggests that even if other strains were eliminated and 39 NAP1/RT027 did not compete for hosts, the continual importation 40 of colonised and infected individuals would be required to sustain 41 endemic disease in the study hospital. If we perform the same 42 analysis for the pooled non-NAP1/RT027 strains in the study 43 (approximately 212 of 334 colonisations and infections were 44 present on admission) the equivalent upper bounds for the in-45 vasion reproduction number and basic reproduction number are 46 both approximately 0.4. Therefore, it appears that NAP1/RT027, though importation-driven, was better adapted for transmission 48 in the study hospital than other strains. 49 It is worth providing some clarifying remarks about how these 50 estimates of reproduction numbers should and should not be 51 interpreted. As noted in Section 3.3, these reproduction num-52 bers do not include any secondary cases that may arise from 53 the primary case following discharge, either in the community 54 or during a subsequent readmission to a hospital (either the 55 same hospital or a different one). A reproduction number that 56 counted these secondary cases would be strictly higher than 57 those estimated here. Nevertheless, the reproduction numbers 58 estimated here are threshold parameters for disease extinction 59 in individual hospitals in the absence of imported cases. Since 60 our calculations suggest that this reproduction number is likely to 61 be below the critical threshold of one, it follows that preventing 62 the admission of colonised individuals, or the effective isolation 63 of patients colonised at admission would drive within-hospital 64 transmission to extinction, a conclusion corroborated by some 65 quasi-experimental studies (Longtin et al., 2016). However, note 66 that this conclusion would hold true even if all patients who 67 are colonised on admission are patients who have acquired the 68 pathogen in a previous hospital stay. Consequently, based on 69 these calculations alone, we cannot conclude that eliminating all 70 transmission in hospitals would not also eliminate (or dramati-71 cally reduce) the proportion of admissions that are colonised at 72 admission. In other words, the calculations in this paper imply 73 that the admission of colonised patients is essential for the main-74 tenance of endemicity in hospitals, but do not imply the converse 75 statement, that within-hospital transmission is not essential for 76 the maintenance of endemicity in hospitals. Nevertheless, we 77 have previously used models of C. difficile transmission in hos-78 pitals and the broader community that are better able to answer 79 this question to demonstrate that this converse is also likely to 80 hold in most settings (McLure et al., 2019a,b).

One can calculate the normalised 18 derivatives of equilibrium prevalence to estimate the reduction 19 in prevalence achieved by a small reduction in each kind of 20 transmission. For example, in the homogenous SIS model with 21 reservoir-exposure, a greater reduction in prevalence is achieved 22 by reducing reservoir exposure only if more than half of cases 23 are acquired from the reservoir 1 . A similar rule can be derived for the 25 SIS model with imported cases. 26 The major limitation of our method is the assumption that the 27 disease and population are at equilibrium. Many diseases, includ-28 ing our case study disease C. difficile, exhibit seasonal variation 29 (Furuya-Kanamori et al., 2015b). It is possible that an infec-30 tion is sufficiently transmissible to be locally sustained in high-31 transmission seasons, but reservoir-driven or importation-driven 32 in low-transmission seasons (Churcher et al., 2014). Similarly, it 33 possible that exposure to the reservoir is seasonal (Rodriguez-34 Palacios et al., 2009). It is possible that an epidemic in one setting 35 is driven by exposure to a population or reservoir where an 36 epidemic is ongoing. Our model does not account for these kinds 37 of temporal variability when estimating reproduction numbers 38 and reservoir-driven thresholds. 39 The simplicity, minimal data requirements, generality and ex-40 tensibility of the method we have presented here make it useful 41 starting point for understanding the impact and interaction of 42 transmission sources both internal and external to a population.
